channel.title: BBC News - Africa
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Convicted ex-Chadian leader Hissène Habré dies at 79
item.description: The former president, whose government carried out 40,000 murders, was serving a life sentence.

item.title: Zambia President Hakainde Hichilema: No-one should go to bed hungry
item.description: Hakainde Hichilema says in his inauguration address he will deal with the high cost of living.

item.title: The Angolan soldier who became a London pub legend
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.

item.title: Mozambique 'tuna bond' scandal: Ex-President Guebuza's son on trial
item.description: Mozambique's biggest corruption scandal led donors to cut funding and an economic crisis.

item.title: Tanzania's Samia Suluhu Hassan criticised over female footballers comments
item.description: The country's first female president recently told the BBC about facing gender discrimination.

item.title: Hakainde Hichilema: Zambia's new president inspires African opposition leaders
item.description: Long-suffering politicians hope to copy Hakainde Hichilema, who was elected at his sixth time attempt.

item.title: Barakat: First South African film in Cape Town's Afrikaans dialect
item.description: Barakat, or blessing, is the first film in Afrikaaps - a dialect of Afrikaans spoken in Cape Town.

item.title: Algeria's desperate wildfire fight: Buckets and branches
item.description: Despite a huge military budget, oil-rich Algeria is ill-equipped to tackle annual fires.

item.title: Nigeria's royal wedding: Private jets, glitz and glamour
item.description: President Buhari's son marries the daughter of a religious leader in one of Nigeria's events of the year.

item.title: Africa's jihadists: What Taliban takeover of Afghanistan means
item.description: Islamist groups appear emboldened by the fall of Afghanistan, sparking concern in African countries.

item.title: Africa's week in pictures: 13-19 August 2021
item.description: A selection of the best photos from the African continent and beyond.

item.title: Tigray crisis: Ethiopian teenagers become pawns in propaganda war
item.description: The BBC is told they were forced to fight for Tigray's rebels, but were words put into their mouths?

item.title: Algeria: The forest fires that led to an artist's lynching
item.description: When Djamel Ben Ismail went to fight forest fires in Algeria, his life was cut short by a raging mob.

item.title: Kenya holds biggest ever animal census
item.description: All wildlife on land and sea is being counted to help Kenya's conservation plans and tourism.

item.title: How could Africa produce its own vaccines?
item.description: For decades, Africa has imported 99% of its vaccines. So how could it jumpstart local vaccine manufacturing?

item.title: Nigeria's Lai Mohammed: We are winning the war against Boko Haram
item.description: The information minister says Nigeria is winning the war against insecurity and is negotiating with Twitter over the ban.

item.title: South African entrepreneur builds a brand against gangsterism
item.description: Roemello Shembe, 21, is building a business in one of Johannesburg’s most challenging townships.

item.title: Zambia elections: Hakainde Hichilema supporters celebrate victory
item.description: People take to the streets following Hakainde Hichilema's landslide victory in Zambia's presidential elections.

item.title: Wildfires rage in Algeria as heatwave hits North Africa
item.description: The blazes in the mountainous Kabylie region are some of the worst in the country's history.

item.title: The illegal gold mines killing rivers and livelihoods in Ghana
item.description: Sixty percent of Ghana's water bodies are now polluted, largely due to illegal mining operations.
